world.setting: A plain soccer penalty field with a single goal and a simple scoreboard by the side. Short grass, open sky, and quiet sidelines to keep the scene clear.

characters.name: First Team
characters.role: The first team: the side that kicks first in the shoot-out.
characters.appearance: A simple human soccer team wearing blue shirts, white shorts, and black cleats. One kicker steps up when it's their turn; the rest stand together by midfield.
characters.emotional_style: Usually calm and steady, often confident when leading.

characters.name: Second Team
characters.role: The second team: the side that kicks after the first team.
characters.appearance: A simple human soccer team wearing red shirts, white shorts, and black cleats. One kicker steps up when it's their turn; the rest wait together by midfield.
characters.emotional_style: Sometimes a bit tense, especially when trailing, but trying to stay brave.

characters.name: Referee
characters.role: A friendly referee who explains what the results mean.
characters.appearance: A calm adult in a black referee uniform with a small whistle and a watch.
characters.emotional_style: Clear, fair, and helpful, pointing out what the scores show.

style_rules: Soft, simple picture-book style with gentle colors.
No written WORDS or sentences inside the images.
Simple numeric scoreboards (like '3–1') are allowed when needed.
Do not introduce any new characters after page 1.
The hero, comparison character (if any), and guide ALWAYS keep the same body shapes, species, and main colors on every page.
Pick exactly ONE type of outcome object for this story (use soccer balls) and use it on all pages.
Keep each scene very simple with only a few important objects.
Scenes should show final results or clear current states, not complicated sequences of actions.

pages.title: Who Kicks First?
pages.caption: It’s a penalty shoot-out. First Team will kick first, and Second Team will go after. We want to see if starting first changes who wins.
pages.visual_prompt: On the penalty field, First Team’s kicker stands at the spot with one soccer ball ready. Second Team waits a few steps behind. The scoreboard shows 0–0. Referee points toward the goal to start.
pages.related_claim: Main problem: does order change performance and winning?

pages.title: First Team Wins More
pages.caption: Across many shoot-outs, the team that starts first wins more. Starting first gives them an edge.
pages.visual_prompt: On the field after many games, a big pile of soccer balls sits beside First Team and a smaller pile sits beside Second Team. Referee stands calmly between the two piles. No action, just the two piles showing who has more wins.
pages.related_claim: Claim 1: Going first raises the chance of winning.

pages.title: Often Ahead as Kicks Go On
pages.caption: As the rounds pass, the first team is more often in front. Being ahead feels easier.
pages.visual_prompt: Mid-shoot-out moment: the scoreboard shows 2–1. Two soccer balls are neatly stacked near First Team and one near Second Team to match the score. First Team looks calm; Second Team looks a bit tense. Referee watches quietly.
pages.related_claim: Claim 3: The first team is more often leading as rounds progress.

pages.title: Being Behind Feels Heavy
pages.caption: When a team is behind, the next kicker is more likely to miss. This happens more to the second team.
pages.visual_prompt: Second Team’s kicker has just shot and a soccer ball lies outside the goal line near the post (a clear miss). The scoreboard shows 2–3, with Second Team trailing. Referee holds one hand out to signal the miss.
pages.related_claim: Claim 4: Being behind lowers a kicker’s chance to score.

pages.title: Calm Kicks Go In
pages.caption: When not behind, the first team’s kicker scores more. Feeling calm helps the ball go in.
pages.visual_prompt: First Team’s kicker has just scored; one soccer ball is sitting in the net. The scoreboard shows 3–1. Referee points to the center to confirm the goal.
pages.related_claim: Claims 3 and 4: First team scores more as state stays favorable; pressure explains the gap.

pages.title: Players Choose to Start
pages.caption: Pros know this. Almost everyone picks to go first to add pressure on the other team.
pages.visual_prompt: Referee offers the first soccer ball to First Team while Second Team nods. The scoreboard simply shows the number 96. No other action.
pages.related_claim: Claim 2: Professionals prefer to kick first.

pages.title: The Clear Lesson
pages.caption: Order matters. Starting first usually means more goals and more wins, because pressure changes how people kick.
pages.visual_prompt: Side by side at the end: a larger pile of soccer balls by First Team and a smaller pile by Second Team. The scoreboard shows 5–3. Referee smiles gently, hands folded.
pages.related_claim: Overall finding: Going first significantly increases the chance of winning.
